{
  "article_text": [
    "cluster algebras were introduced by fomin and zelevinsky in  @xcite , and have since found applications across many types of mathematics . these are commutative subalgebras of @xmath0 generated by rational functions constructed using a certain combinatorial procedure starting from an initial seed which produces that seed s mutation class .    in the same paper fomin and zelevinsky",
    "defined the exchange graph of a cluster algebra to better visualise the combinatorics of the mutation class .",
    "these graphs proved a useful tool in their classification of finite - type cluster algebras in  @xcite where these algebras were shown to correspond to dynkin diagrams .",
    "cluster algebras were shown to be closely related to triangulations of surfaces by fomin , shapiro and thurston in  @xcite , where a quiver is constructed from a given triangulation and quiver mutations correspond to flipping an edge in the triangulation .",
    "these quivers from surfaces play an important role in the classification of mutation - finite quivers , given by felikson , shapiro and tumarkin in  @xcite , as all such quivers are mutation - finite and there are only 11 other exceptional mutation classes .    in a similar fashion triangulations of orbifolds with orbifold points of order 2 were shown to correspond to mutation - finite diagrams by felikson , shapiro and tumarkin in  @xcite .",
    "unfoldings of diagrams , introduced by felikson , shapiro and tumarkin in  @xcite , then correspond to coverings of the orbifold by a triangulated surface , as shown in  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 12 ) .",
    "cluster automorphisms were introduced by assem , schiffler and shramchenko in  @xcite , for cluster algebras generated from quivers , as automorphisms of the cluster algebra taking clusters to clusters and acting as either the identity or the opposite function on quivers .",
    "these ideas were extended to cluster algebras generated from certain skew - symmetrizable matrices by chang and zhu in  @xcite .",
    "the group of cluster automorphisms of a cluster algebra arising from the triangulation of a surface was shown to be isomorphic to the mapping class group of this surface by brstle and qiu in  @xcite .",
    "in their paper on labelled seeds and global mutations  @xcite , king and pressland showed that cluster automorphisms arise naturally when mutation classes are considered as orbits of labelled seeds under the action of a global mutation group @xmath1 .",
    "the group of cluster automorphisms is a subgroup of the automorphisms of these mutation classes , @xmath2 , which commute with this group action , and in fact for mutation - finite quivers these groups are isomorphic .",
    "we use the links between automorphisms of the exchange graph and the labelled exchange graph to prove that this group @xmath2 is isomorphic to the group of exchange graph automorphisms :    for a labelled mutation class @xmath3 with mutation class @xmath4 and exchange graph @xmath5 @xmath6    therefore for mutation - finite quivers , such as those from triangulations of a surface , exchange graph automorphisms are cluster automorphisms .    for a cluster algebra",
    "@xmath7 constructed from a mutation - finite quiver with exchange graph @xmath8 @xmath9    this result was proved in a different way by chang and zhu in  @xcite who also proved an extension of this to skew - symmetrizable matrices of type @xmath10 and @xmath11 for @xmath12 .",
    "however for other skew - symmetrizable matrices it is not true that exchange graph automorphisms are cluster automorphisms .",
    "it can be shown that the group of cluster automorphisms is isomorphic to a subgroup of the group of exchange graph automorphisms but in general there exist graph automorphisms which do not correspond to cluster automorphisms .    in order to generalise these results",
    "we introduce a marking on the exchange graph in such a way that any automorphism which fixes these markings does in fact correspond to a cluster automorphism .",
    "let @xmath13 be a seed where @xmath14 is a mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrix with cluster algebra @xmath7 and marked exchange graph @xmath15 then @xmath16    therefore the cluster automorphisms of any cluster algebra generated by mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrices can be studied using just the combinatorial properties of its marked exchange graph .    a skew - symmetrizable matrix associated to a good orbifold with order 2 orbifold points can be unfolded to a skew - symmetric matrix associated to a surface which covers the orbifold . in this case",
    "we show that automorphisms of the marked exchange graph induce automorphisms of the unfolded exchange graph .    given a skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath14 which unfolds to a matrix @xmath17 , with corresponding marked exchange graphs @xmath18 and @xmath19 , @xmath20    we finish the paper with a conjecture generalising a result of brstle and qiu linking the tagged mapping class group of a surface with the cluster automorphisms of the corresponding surface cluster algebra .    for a cluster algebra @xmath7 arising from the triangulation of an orbifold @xmath21 @xmath22",
    "the structure of the paper is as follows : section  [ sec : mut ] gives basic definitions of cluster algebras and mutations while section  [ sec : exch ] looks at the exchange graph of a cluster algebra and includes proofs linking graph automorphisms and mutation class automorphisms .",
    "section  [ sec : clauts ] recalls the definition of cluster automorphisms and various known results linking these to mutation class automorphisms and exchange graph automorphisms .",
    "the section ends by explaining how a maximal green sequence of an acyclic quiver can be used to construct a cluster automorphism .    in section  [ sec : exchauts ] we introduce the marked exchange graph which enables us to extend these results to cluster algebras from skew - symmetrizable matrices .",
    "we show that graph automorphisms fixing the marking are in one - to - one correspondence with cluster automorphisms .    in section  [ sec",
    ": unf ] we consider unfoldings of skew - symmetrizable matrices and show how the cluster automorphisms of a skew - symmetrizable cluster algebra induce cluster automorphisms of its unfolded cluster algebra",
    ". section  [ sec : mcg ] looks at these ideas when the skew - symmetrizable cluster algebra is constructed from an orbifold and its unfolding gives a surface cluster algebra .",
    "a _ skew - symmetric _ matrix is a matrix @xmath23 such that @xmath24 .",
    "a _ skew - symmetrizable _ matrix is a matrix @xmath14 such that there exists some diagonal integer matrix @xmath25 with positive diagonal entries for which @xmath26 is a skew - symmetric matrix .",
    "such a matrix with the smallest entries is called the _ symmetrizing matrix _ of @xmath14 .",
    "a _ quiver _ is an oriented graph possibly with multiple arrows between two vertices and in this paper we always assume that it is restricted to having no loops or 2-cycles . if @xmath17 is a quiver , then its _ opposite _",
    "@xmath27 is the quiver constructed by reversing the direction of all arrows in @xmath17 .    the restrictions on the definition of a quiver",
    "ensure that quivers are in one - to - one correspondence with skew - symmetric matrices .",
    "a given skew - symmetric matrix @xmath28 defines a quiver with @xmath29 vertices and @xmath30 arrows from the @xmath31-th vertex to the @xmath32-th vertex if @xmath33 .",
    "a _ diagram _ is a weighted oriented graph which does not have multiple arrows between any two vertices , in addition to having no loops or 2-cycles , where the weights on the edges are positive integers .",
    "similarly to quivers , if @xmath34 is a diagram then its _ opposite _",
    "@xmath35 is constructed by reversing all arrows in @xmath34 .    unlike with quivers",
    ", there is no one - to - one correspondence between diagrams and skew - symmetrizable matrices .",
    "given a skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath36 we can construct a diagram with @xmath29 vertices and an arrow from the @xmath31-th vertex to the @xmath32-th vertex with weight @xmath37 if @xmath33 .",
    "usually weights of @xmath38 are omitted and just shown as an unweighted arrow .",
    "however a diagram only corresponds to a matrix if the product of weights along any chordless cycle is a perfect square and in this case may correspond to multiple matrices .    throughout this paper",
    "we assume that all quivers and diagrams are connected .",
    "the results can be easily extended to disconnected diagrams , however care must be taken as different connected components could have their arrows reversed while other components do not , so the idea of an opposite diagram is less clear .",
    "let @xmath39 .",
    "a _ cluster _ is a set of algebraically independent elements of @xmath40 , while a _ labelled cluster _ is a cluster with some ordering of its elements .",
    "the individual elements in a cluster are called _",
    "cluster variables_.    a _ labelled seed _ is a pair @xmath13 where @xmath14 is a skew - symmetrizable matrix and @xmath41 is a labelled cluster .",
    "each cluster variable in the cluster can be thought of as being attached to one of the matrix rows , or equivalently attached to one of the vertices of the corresponding quiver or diagram .",
    "seed _ is a class of labelled seeds which differ only by permutations .    throughout this paper",
    "we assume that the matrix in a seed is uniquely determined by its cluster .",
    "this has been proved for all cluster algebras of geometric type or generated from a non - degenerate matrix by gekhtman , shapiro and vainshtein in  @xcite . in this case",
    "denote the matrix for a given cluster @xmath41 by @xmath42 .    given a labelled seed @xmath43 , where @xmath44 and @xmath45 , then the _ mutation _",
    "@xmath46 acts on @xmath47 to give @xmath48 where @xmath49 and @xmath50 given by @xmath51 @xmath52    it is sometimes convenient to consider the local mutation @xmath53 of a seed @xmath13 corresponding to the mutation at the vertex associated to the cluster variable @xmath54 .",
    "these local mutations act as functions on seeds , whereas global mutations act on labelled seeds .",
    "permutations act on a labelled seed @xmath55 , @xmath56 , @xmath45 in the expected way taking the @xmath31-th vertex to the @xmath57-th vertex and the @xmath31-th cluster variable to the @xmath57-th cluster variable .",
    "therefore @xmath58 where @xmath59 and @xmath60 , @xmath61 .",
    "given a 3 vertex seed @xmath62 as in figure  [ fig : permex ] and permutation @xmath63 then @xmath64 maps the first vertex and cluster variable to the third , second to first and third to second .",
    "therefore @xmath65 , @xmath66 and @xmath67 . similarly @xmath68 and @xmath69 .",
    "@xmath70    the _ global mutation group _ for seeds of rank @xmath29 is given by @xmath71 where the @xmath72 are mutations and @xmath73 for @xmath74 .    the _ labelled mutation class _ @xmath3 of a labelled seed @xmath62 is the orbit of @xmath13 under the action of @xmath1 .",
    "the quotient by the symmetric group action gives the _ mutation class _ @xmath75two seeds in the same mutation class are said to be _ mutation - equivalent_.    the _ cluster algebra _",
    "@xmath76 is the subalgebra of @xmath40 generated by all cluster variables occurring in the seeds in @xmath77 .",
    "a cluster algebra is said to be of _ finite type _ if there are a finite number of generating cluster variables in the mutation class , otherwise it is of _ infinite type_. if there are a finite number of distinct matrices in the seeds of @xmath77 , then the cluster algebra and all the matrices are said to be _ mutation - finite _ or of _ finite mutation type _ , otherwise it is _ mutation - infinite _ or of _ infinite mutation type_.    the mutation class automorphism group @xmath78 is the group of bijections @xmath79 which commute with the action of @xmath1 , so for all @xmath80 , @xmath81 and @xmath82 @xmath83",
    "fomin and zelevinsky in  @xcite developed the idea of the exchange graph of a cluster algebra to better visualise the relations in a mutation class .",
    "these were also an important tool in their classification of finite type cluster algebras in  @xcite .",
    "the _ exchange graph _",
    "@xmath5 of a mutation class @xmath77 is constructed with vertices for each seed in @xmath77 and an edge between two seeds @xmath47 and @xmath84 if and only if there is a single local mutation @xmath85 such that @xmath86 .    the _ labelled exchange graph",
    "_ @xmath87 of a labelled mutation class @xmath3 is constructed with a vertex for each labelled seed in @xmath3 and an edge labelled @xmath31 between two labelled seeds @xmath47 and @xmath84 if and only if @xmath88 ( and conversely @xmath89 ) .    . ]    . ]",
    "the exchange graph for the cluster algebra of type @xmath90 is the well known pentagon , as seen in figure  [ fig : a2-exch ] .",
    "the labelled exchange graph is a decagon shown in figure  [ fig : a2-lexch ] , with the permutation acting by taking a seed to its antipodal seed .    . ]    . ]",
    "the exchange graph for a cluster algebra of type @xmath91 is a hexagon , as shown in figure  [ fig : b2-exch ] .",
    "the labelled exchange graph however is the disjoint union of two hexagons as shown in figure  [ fig : b2-lexch ] .",
    "the permutation interchanging the cluster variables in a labelled seed gives another labelled seed which can not be obtained from the first though just mutations , so any labelled seed has a permuted counterpart in the other connected component .",
    "the _ exchange graph automorphism group _",
    "@xmath92 is the group of permutations @xmath64 of the vertex set of the exchange graph such that there is an edge between two vertices @xmath47 and @xmath84 if and only if there is an edge between @xmath93 and @xmath94 .",
    "the _ labelled exchange graph automorphisms _ in @xmath95 must also preserve the labelling of the edges .",
    "[ thm : pullback ] for a labelled mutation class @xmath3 with quotient @xmath77 and corresponding exchange graphs @xmath87 and @xmath5 , then @xmath96    to show this we construct a unique @xmath97 for each @xmath98 .",

    "it is not true in general that @xmath166 , as @xmath87 can have a number of connected components which are identified under the quotient by the symmetric group action .",
    "any automorphism which changes a single connected component while fixing all others would therefore not project down to an automorphism of @xmath5 .",
    "for example , in the case of the cluster algebra of type @xmath91 , the labelled exchange graph automorphism given by rotating the top hexagon in figure  [ fig : b2-lexch ] while fixing the bottom hexagon would not give any valid exchange graph automorphism",

    "so far in this section we have proved properties of automorphisms of the exchange graph of a cluster algebra . in the remainder of this paper we use these results to compare these exchange graph automorphisms to other automorphisms related to the cluster algebra .",
    "[ thm : mnexch ] for a labelled mutation class @xmath3 with mutation class @xmath4 and exchange graph @xmath5 @xmath6    let @xmath194 and let @xmath195 be the transformation of @xmath5 given by @xmath196 ) = [ \\phi(u)]$ ] .",

    "let @xmath208 be the map given by @xmath209 .",
    "any element of @xmath1 can be written as a product of mutations and permutations , so to prove @xmath194 it suffices to show that @xmath109 commutes with any permutation and any mutation .",
    "let @xmath64 be a permutation , then by proposition  [ prop : deltaperm ] @xmath210 let @xmath47 and @xmath200 be two labelled seeds related by a single mutation , then @xmath211 is an automorphism of @xmath87 , so @xmath212",
    "cluster automorphisms were introduced by assem , schiffler and shramchenko in  @xcite . in their paper",
    "the authors computed some particular examples of automorphism groups and drew links between automorphisms of the cluster algebra of a surface and the mapping class group of that surface .",
    "this correspondence was later proved by brstle and qiu in  @xcite for all surfaces except a select few , as discussed in section  [ sec : mcg ] .",
    "[ def : claut ] a @xmath40-automorphism @xmath213 is a _",
    "cluster automorphism _ of @xmath76 if there exists a seed @xmath13 in @xmath77 such that    1 .",
    "@xmath214 is a cluster .",
    "2 .   for every @xmath215 we have @xmath216 .",
    "cluster automorphisms were originally only defined for skew - symmetric matrices and hence quivers , but the same definitions and some results apply to skew - symmetrizable matrices as well .",
    "the cluster automorphism groups in this setting were first studied by chang and zhu in  @xcite and  @xcite .",
    "recall that throughout this paper we assume that the cluster @xmath41 of a seed uniquely determines the seed s matrix , and in this case the matrix is denoted @xmath42 .",
    "[ lem : clautmatrix ] if @xmath213 is a @xmath40-automorphism , then @xmath213 is a cluster automorphism if and only if there exists a seed @xmath62 such that @xmath214 is a cluster and @xmath217 or @xmath144 .",
    "the definition of a cluster automorphism only requires that there exists a single seed such that the image is a seed and the automorphism is compatible with mutations of that seed , however the compatibility with mutations allows these properties to be extended to all seeds in the cluster algebra .    let @xmath213 be a cluster automorphism of a cluster algebra @xmath7 , then @xmath213 satisfies the conditions in definition  [ def : claut ] and lemma  [ lem : clautmatrix ] for every seed in @xmath7 .",
    "this therefore gives two ways of thinking of cluster automorphisms as either automorphisms taking clusters to clusters which are compatible with mutations or as automorphisms which fix exchange matrices ( up to multiplication by -1 ) .",
    "a cluster automorphism which fixes exchange matrices is called a _ direct _ cluster automorphism , whereas those which send an exchange matrix @xmath14 to @xmath144 are called _ inverse _ cluster automorphisms .",
    "cluster automorphisms form a group , so let @xmath218 denote the group of all cluster automorphisms of @xmath7 , and @xmath219 be the subgroup of direct cluster automorphisms .",
    "let @xmath7 be a cluster algebra generated by an exchange matrix @xmath14 .",
    "if @xmath14 is mutation - equivalent to @xmath144 then @xmath220 is a normal subgroup of @xmath218 with index 2 , otherwise @xmath221 .",
    "cluster automorphisms arise naturally in the labelled seed and global mutation setting introduced by king and pressland , with the following correspondence :    [ thm : mutfinquiver ] if @xmath77 is the mutation class of a seed @xmath222 where @xmath17 is a skew - symmetric mutation - finite matrix then @xmath223    combining theorem  [ thm : mutfinquiver ] with theorem  [ thm : mnexch ] gives the following :    [ cor : mfquiv - exchaut ] for a cluster algebra @xmath7 constructed from a mutation - finite quiver with exchange graph @xmath8 @xmath9    chang and zhu provide an alternative proof of this in  @xcite and extend the result to certain finite type skew - symmetrizable matrices :    [ thm : bncn ] if @xmath77 is the mutation class of a seed @xmath13 where @xmath14 is a skew - symmetrizable matrix of dynkin type @xmath10 or @xmath11 for @xmath12 then @xmath224      maximal green sequences are certain sequences of mutations of a given quiver .",
    "first studied by keller in  @xcite in relation to quantum dilogarithms they have subsequently been used to study bps states in theoretical physics ( see for example  @xcite ) .    in their paper on maximal green sequences , brstle , dupont and protin proved that any maximal green sequence for some quiver @xmath17 takes it to a quiver which is isomorphic to @xmath17  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 2.10 ) .",
    "hence this sequence of mutations will give an element of the mutation group @xmath225 which takes a cluster to a cluster and a quiver @xmath17 to an isomorphic quiver @xmath226 , with some permutation @xmath64 which acts on the vertices of @xmath226 to give @xmath17 .",
    "then @xmath227 fixes the quiver and therefore induces a cluster automorphism .    given a quiver @xmath17 ,",
    "its _ framed quiver _",
    "@xmath228 ( respectively _ coframed _ quiver @xmath229 ) is the quiver constructed from @xmath17 by adding an additional vertex @xmath230 and an additional arrow @xmath231 ( resp .",
    "@xmath232 ) for each vertex @xmath31 of @xmath17 .",
    "these additional vertices are considered frozen vertices of the ( co)framed quiver . for a quiver",
    "@xmath17 call this set of frozen vertices of the quiver @xmath233 .    given a quiver @xmath17 with framed quiver @xmath228 , a non - frozen vertex @xmath31 of a quiver @xmath34 in the mutation class of @xmath228 is called _ green _ ( resp .  _ red _ ) if for each @xmath234 there is no arrow @xmath235 ( resp .",
    "no arrow @xmath236 ) in the quiver @xmath34 .",
    "every ( non - frozen ) vertex in a quiver of the mutation class of @xmath228 is either green or red  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 2.6 ) .",
    "a maximal green sequence is then a sequence of mutations at green vertices which continues until every non - frozen vertex is red .",
    "the quiver of type @xmath90 has framed and coframed quivers as shown in figure  [ fig : framed - a2 ] .",
    "this quiver has two maximal green sequences given by @xmath237 and @xmath238 which are illustrated in figure  [ fig : green - seq - a2 ] .",
    "( left ) , with its framed quiver ( center ) and coframed quiver ( right ) .",
    "green vertices are shown as circles , red vertices as crosses and frozen vertices as plusses . ]     starting with its framed quiver .",
    "the top green sequence is @xmath237 and the bottom is @xmath239 .",
    "the two resulting quivers are both isomorphic to the coframed quiver of the quiver of type @xmath90 .",
    "green vertices are shown as circles , red vertices as crosses and frozen vertices as plusses . ]",
    "if the initial labelled seed is @xmath240 with cluster @xmath241 , then the resulting cluster after these green sequences induces a cluster automorphism as shown below",
    ". the sequence @xmath238 does not give the same quiver , but after the permutation @xmath242 it does : @xmath243these both give the same cluster automorphism @xmath244 and @xmath245 .",
    "theorems  [ thm : mutfinquiver ] and  [ thm : bncn ] show that cluster automorphisms are linked to the automorphisms of the exchange graph for mutation - finite skew - symmetric matrices as well as a specific family of skew - symmetrizable matrices . however , in general the exchange graph automorphism group for any mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrix is larger than the cluster automorphism group .",
    "an example of this would be the exchange graph automorphism of the mutation class of @xmath91 considered in example  [ ex : b2-exchaut ] .",
    "this graph automorphism does not correspond to a cluster automorphism as the initial matrix @xmath14 is sent to @xmath246 .    in this section",
    "we aim to generalise the results of the previous section to the skew - symmetrizable case .",
    "to do this we introduce additional structure on the exchange graph , which defines a marked exchange graph .",
    "this extra structure ensures that any graph automorphism fixing this structure corresponds to a cluster automorphism . in this way",
    "the study of cluster automorphisms can be reduced to the combinatorial study of graph automorphisms .",
    "let @xmath14 be a skew - symmetrizable matrix , with symmetrizing matrix @xmath25 . if @xmath72 is any mutation , then @xmath25 is also the symmetrizing matrix for @xmath247 .",
    "similarly for any permutation @xmath64 the permuted matrix @xmath248 is the symmetrizing matrix for @xmath249 .",
    "the _ marked labelled exchange graph _ of a mutation class generated by @xmath128 where @xmath14 is a skew - symmetrizable matrix with symmetrizing matrix @xmath250 is the labelled exchange graph with an additional marking on each edge .",
    "each edge corresponds to a global mutation @xmath72 for some @xmath31 , so mark that edge with the symmetrizing entry @xmath251 .",
    "if a permutation @xmath64 acts on @xmath47 to give a labelled seed in a different component of @xmath87 , then mark the @xmath31-th edges with @xmath252 , where @xmath253 .    in the exchange graph @xmath125",
    "each edge no longer corresponds to a global mutation @xmath72 , but rather to a local mutation @xmath53 at a specific cluster variable @xmath254 in a cluster @xmath41 .    for a permutation @xmath64 and permuted seed @xmath255",
    ", then the edge @xmath185 adjacent to this seed corresponds to the local mutation @xmath256 } = \\mu_{\\beta_i , [ \\textbf{x}]}$ ] as @xmath257 and @xmath258 = [ \\textbf{x}]$ ] .",
    "this edge @xmath185 is marked with @xmath259 and hence in the quotient the edge @xmath260 has a consistent marking , so the following is well - defined .",
    "let @xmath261 be the _ marked exchange graph _ of a mutation class @xmath77 given by taking the quotient of the marked labelled exchange graph with respect to the symmetric group action .",
    "alternatively let @xmath14 be a skew - symmetrizable matrix , with symmetrizing matrix @xmath25 and let @xmath34 be the diagram corresponding to @xmath14 so each row in @xmath14 represents a vertex in @xmath34 . each diagonal entry in @xmath25 can be thought of as being attached to that row s vertex of @xmath34 , and the edge in @xmath262 representing mutation in that vertex should be marked with this diagonal entry .    .",
    "dotted edges correspond to a symmetrizing entry of @xmath38 , while dashed edges correspond to @xmath263 .",
    "only denominators are shown in the cluster variables with a bar above each , unless the cluster variable is one of @xmath264 or @xmath265 where the variable is shown with a bar underneath . ]",
    "the marked exchange graph of the cluster algebra of type @xmath266 is shown in figure  [ fig : b3-marked ] .",
    "the cluster variables are not written out in full , rather only the denominators are shown with a bar above except for the initial cluster variables @xmath267 , @xmath268 and @xmath265 which are shown with a bar underneath .",
    "each vertex is adjacent to two dotted edges and one dashed edge .",
    "choosing a matrix in the mutation class , the symmetrizing matrix is @xmath269 : @xmath270 the dotted edges correspond to mutations in the vertices with symmetrizing entry @xmath38 , while the dashed edge corresponds to the mutation in the vertex with symmetrizing entry @xmath263 .    in this case ,",
    "any automorphism of the unmarked exchange graph sends dashed edges to dashed edges , so automatically preserves the markings and hence @xmath271 .    .",
    "dotted edges correspond to mutations in a vertex with symmetrizer @xmath38 while dashed edges correspond to symmetrizer @xmath263 . ]",
    "the marked exchange graph of the cluster algebra of type @xmath91 is shown in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] , where dotted edges correspond to mutations in vertices with symmetrizer @xmath38 and dashed edges correspond to symmetrizer @xmath263 .",
    "the initial matrix for the cluster @xmath130 $ ] was chosen to be @xmath272 with symmetrizing matrix @xmath273 .",
    "the automorphism considered in example  [ ex : b2-exchaut ] , given by a rotation of angle @xmath126 , does not fix the markings in the graph , so is not an automorphism of the marked graph .    for any skew - symmetric matrix",
    "the symmetrizing matrix is the identity , so all markings would be the same and @xmath274 .    for a cluster algebra of dynkin type @xmath10 or @xmath11 , for @xmath12 , the marking on the exchange graph does not limit the number of automorphisms , so @xmath275 .",
    "this follows from theorem 3.7 in chang and zhu s paper  @xcite linking exchange graph automorphisms and cluster automorphisms .",
    "let @xmath125 be an exchange graph of a seed @xmath276 with vertices labelled @xmath277 .",
    "for a subset of vertices @xmath278 the _ frozenisation _ of @xmath47 with respect to @xmath278 is the mutation class constructed by freezing all vertices in @xmath278 .",
    "it is often more convenient to consider the _ cofrozenisation _ of @xmath47 with respect to @xmath278 , denoted @xmath279 , which is constructed by freezing all vertices in @xmath47 except those in @xmath278 .",
    "this is then a frozenisation of @xmath47 with respect to @xmath280 .",
    "a _ geodesic loop _",
    "@xmath281 is the exchange graph of a cofrozenisation @xmath282 which leaves only two vertices @xmath283 and @xmath284 unfrozen .",
    "a loop is then either a polygon with @xmath285 or @xmath286 sides or an infinite line , which embeds into the exchange graph of the mutation class of @xmath47 .",
    "the _ distance _ between a geodesic loop @xmath287 and any vertex @xmath84 in @xmath125 is the ( possibly zero ) minimum number of edges in @xmath125 between @xmath84 and any vertex in @xmath287 .",
    "the _ length _ of a geodesic loop @xmath288 is the number of edges in the loop .",
    "geodesic loops as subgraphs of a larger exchange graph give rise to the following sets , which encode the information about a given seed represented by a vertex of the exchange graph .",
    "the following construction is a slight notational variation of the one given by chang and zhu in definition 3.1 of  @xcite .",
    "let @xmath47 be a seed of rank @xmath29 in an exchange graph , then define @xmath289 to be the set of @xmath290 numbers given by the length of all geodesic loops distance @xmath291 from @xmath47 .",
    "similarly define @xmath292 to be the set of @xmath293 numbers given by the lengths of all geodesic loops distance @xmath38 from @xmath47 .",
    "an exchange graph automorphism @xmath137 induces an automorphism @xmath136 and in this way @xmath109 induces a map @xmath294 which takes cluster variables in a seed @xmath47 to variables in @xmath295 .",
    "a geodesic loop @xmath296 in an exchange graph @xmath125 must get mapped to another geodesic loop of the same length by any exchange graph automorphism , however it is not clear that the image of @xmath296 will be generated by the cofrozenisation @xmath297 rather than another cofrozenisation with two different unfrozen vertices in @xmath47 .",
    "the following lemma explains that this must always be the case .",
    "[ lem : fixfrozexch ] let @xmath47 be a seed in a cluster algebra @xmath7 and @xmath298 .",
    "for any two vertices @xmath283 and @xmath284 the geodesic loop @xmath299 is isomorphic to its image @xmath300 .    choose some ordering on @xmath47 so that the vertices @xmath301 and @xmath302 are indexed by @xmath31 and @xmath32 respectively , then the length of the geodesic loop specifies a relation @xmath303 .",
    "for example if the loop has length @xmath304 , then @xmath305 , whereas if the length is @xmath306 then @xmath307 .",
    "the exchange graph automorphism @xmath109 corresponds to some @xmath308 which commutes with the action of @xmath1 .",
    "hence @xmath309 so the geodesic loop @xmath300 has the same length as the geodesic loop @xmath299 , and hence the two loops are isomorphic .",
    "exchange graph automorphisms preserve the combinatorial structure around a seed .",
    "as these automorphisms are compatible with mutations the above result could be extended to the exchange graphs of cofrozenisations with any number of unfrozen vertices .",
    "[ lem : npreserved ] if @xmath137 is an exchange graph automorphism , with @xmath47 a seed and @xmath310 its image , then @xmath311 and @xmath312 .",
    "[ lem : ndefinesb ] given a mutation - finite diagram with at least 3 vertices , the exchange graph of a frozenisation leaving just two vertices unfrozen determines the weight on the arrow between the two unfrozen vertices .",
    "the exchange graph of the frozenisation leaving just two vertices @xmath283 and @xmath284 unfrozen is a geodesic loop @xmath313 with length @xmath314 .",
    "if @xmath315 then the vertices have no arrow between them , while if @xmath316 there is a single unweighted arrow .",
    "if @xmath317 then there is an arrow weighted @xmath263 and @xmath318 shows there is an arrow weighted @xmath319 .",
    "the highest edge weight in a mutation - finite diagram ( with more than 2 vertices ) is @xmath320 , so @xmath321 implies that there is an arrow weighted @xmath320 .    for any @xmath263-vertex diagram @xmath14 , an edge weight of @xmath320 or more will always give @xmath321 ,",
    "so the exchange graph can not determine this weight .",
    "however the only diagrams mutation - equivalent to @xmath14 are @xmath14 and @xmath322 , so all diagrams in the same mutation class have the same edge weight .",
    "[ lem : unoriented ] an exchange graph automorphism @xmath137 takes a seed @xmath276 to another seed @xmath323 where the unoriented diagram of @xmath324 is the same as the unoriented diagram of @xmath14 .",
    "fix any two vertices @xmath325 and @xmath326 in @xmath47 . under @xmath294",
    "these vertices are mapped to corresponding vertices @xmath327 and @xmath328 in @xmath84 .",
    "the weight on ( or absence of ) the arrow between @xmath325 and @xmath326 determines the exchange graph @xmath329 of the cofrozenisation @xmath330 . by lemma  [ lem : fixfrozexch ]",
    ", @xmath329 is isomorphic to the exchange graph @xmath331 of the cofrozenisation @xmath332 .",
    "hence this exchange graph determines the arrow between @xmath333 and @xmath334 by lemmas  [ lem : npreserved ] and  [ lem : ndefinesb ] , which necessarily must be the same as that between @xmath325 and @xmath326 .",
    "this shows that the unoriented diagrams of two seeds related by an exchange graph automorphism must be the same . to see how exchange graphs automorphisms affect the orientations of the arrows we need to consider frozenisations with three unfrozen vertices .",
    "[ lem:3vert - n ] for any seed @xmath276 with 3 vertices in an exchange graph of a mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable diagram , the diagram of @xmath14 is determined by the sets @xmath289 and @xmath292 , up to reversing all arrows .",
    "the unoriented diagram of @xmath14 is determined by @xmath335 , where each @xmath336 determines a weighted arrow , or absence of arrow , between two vertices .",
    "the orientation of @xmath14 ( up to reversing all arrows ) is given by @xmath292 as shown in tables  [ tab : diconnn ] ,  [ tab : symmetricn ] and  [ tab : symmetrizn ] , where all mutation - finite 3-vertex diagrams are illustrated along with their defining sets @xmath337 and @xmath338 .",
    "hence the pair @xmath339 defines a unique diagram , up to reversing all arrows .                in the case",
    "@xmath340 the diagram is of the form :        where the weight satisfies @xmath341 and so the diagram is not uniquely determined .",
    "however if @xmath342 then the resulting diagram will never appear as a subdiagram of any larger mutation - finite diagram .",
    "this is precisely the setup used in the proofs below and so @xmath340 is always assumed to correspond to a diagram of the form :        [ prop : exchdiagram ] let @xmath137 be an exchange graph automorphism and @xmath128 a seed where @xmath14 is a mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrix with corresponding connected diagram @xmath34 . in the image @xmath343 ,",
    "the diagram @xmath344 corresponding to the matrix @xmath324 is either @xmath34 or @xmath35 .",
    "choose any 3 vertices @xmath345 in @xmath47 , then by lemma  [ lem : fixfrozexch ] there is an isomorphism @xmath346 and @xmath347 , @xmath348 .",
    "therefore by lemma  [ lem:3vert - n ] the subdiagram @xmath349 of @xmath34 consisting just of the arrows between @xmath350 and @xmath351 is the same as the subdiagram @xmath352 of @xmath344 consisting of the arrows between @xmath353 and @xmath354 , up to reversing all arrows .",
    "choose a fourth vertex @xmath355 and consider the 3-vertex subdiagram @xmath356 on the vertex set @xmath357 .",
    "by the same reasoning as above the image @xmath358 must be the same , but possibly with all arrows reversed .",
    "however both @xmath352 and @xmath359 share the edge between vertices @xmath360 and @xmath354 , so if @xmath361 then @xmath362 whereas if @xmath363 then @xmath364 .",
    "as @xmath34 is connected , by successively choosing different vertices , the whole diagram @xmath344 must either be the same as @xmath34 or @xmath35 .",
    "this shows that any exchange graph automorphism takes clusters to clusters and a diagram to itself or its opposite .",
    "however this is not enough to show that these automorphisms are cluster automorphisms , as this requires the matrix @xmath14 of the diagram to be sent to @xmath365 . for this",
    "we require the markings on the exchange graph .",
    "[ prop : mexchmatrix ] given a marked exchange graph automorphism @xmath366 and a seed @xmath367 with image @xmath368 , then the matrix @xmath369 or @xmath144 .",
    "let @xmath34 be the diagram associated to @xmath14 , and let @xmath344 be the diagram associated to @xmath324 .",
    "let @xmath370 be the symmetrizing matrix for @xmath14 , each vertex @xmath371 in @xmath47 has a symmetrizing multiplier , which marked exchange graph automorphisms preserve , so each vertex @xmath372 in @xmath295 has the same symmetrizing multiplier as @xmath371 and @xmath373 .    by proposition  [ prop : exchdiagram ] , @xmath344 is the same as @xmath34 or @xmath35 with symmetrizing matrix @xmath374 which defines the skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath369 or @xmath144 .",
    "these results ensure that a marked exchange graph automorphism fixes matrices in seeds and so correspond to cluster automorphisms . in this way we generalise corollary  [ cor : mfquiv - exchaut ] to all mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrices .",
    "[ thm : mexchaut ] for a seed @xmath13 where @xmath14 is a mutation - finite skew - symmetrizable matrix with mutation class @xmath77 , cluster algebra @xmath375 and marked exchange graph",
    "@xmath15 then @xmath16    a cluster automorphism @xmath376 satisfies the following properties :    * @xmath214 is a cluster * @xmath213 is compatible with mutations * @xmath377 or @xmath144    for all seeds @xmath378 in the mutation class @xmath77 .",
    "such an automorphism induces an automorphism of the exchange graph , and as @xmath213 sends a matrix @xmath14 to @xmath365 it also fixes the symmetrizing matrix so fixes the marking on the exchange graph .",
    "therefore @xmath379 and @xmath380 .    to show that @xmath381 let @xmath13 be a labelled seed , with mutation class @xmath3 and quotient @xmath77 .",
    "if @xmath382 , then by theorem  [ thm : pullback ] this pulls back to an automorphism @xmath97 . then the image @xmath383 where @xmath384 gives an automorphism @xmath385 defined by @xmath386",
    "this @xmath213 then corresponds to @xmath109 , so @xmath214 is a cluster and it remains to show that @xmath387 , however this follows from proposition  [ prop : mexchmatrix ] so @xmath388 .",
    "many skew - symmetrizable matrices @xmath14 have unfoldings to skew - symmetric matrices @xmath389 , which extend to seeds , where a given seed in @xmath390 unfolds to a seed in @xmath391 .",
    "the corresponding exchange graphs are related , with the marked exchange graph @xmath18 embedding into the exchange graph @xmath392 provided edges marked in certain ways split into multiple edges .",
    "given a skew - symmetrizable @xmath393 matrix @xmath45 with symmetrizing matrix @xmath250 , let @xmath394 and partition the set @xmath395 into @xmath29 disjoint consecutive index sets @xmath396 such that @xmath397 for all @xmath32 .",
    "construct a skew - symmetric @xmath398 matrix @xmath389 where :    1 .",
    "[ enum : unfdefa ] the sum of entries in each column of each @xmath399 block equals @xmath30 .",
    "[ enum : unfdefb ] if @xmath33 then all entries in the @xmath399 block are non - negative .",
    "[ enum : unfdefc ] all entries in each @xmath400 block are zero .    given @xmath401 and any @xmath402 the corresponding mutations @xmath403 and @xmath46 commute .",
    "the @xmath31-th _ composite mutation _",
    "@xmath404 of @xmath389 is given by @xmath405 the matrix @xmath389 is the _ unfolding _ of @xmath14 if the matrix @xmath406 satisfies the conditions  [ enum : unfdefa ] and  [ enum : unfdefb ] above with respect to the matrix @xmath407 for any sequence of mutations @xmath408 with corresponding composite mutations @xmath409 .    a labelled seed @xmath410 , b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] , with skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath14 , unfolds in the same way to @xmath411 , c { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] where @xmath389 is the unfolding of @xmath14 .",
    "the @xmath32-th row in @xmath14 corresponds to the cluster variable @xmath412 and this row unfolds to @xmath413 rows in @xmath389 , hence @xmath412 unfolds to @xmath413 cluster variables @xmath414 .",
    "a diagram has a finite number of distinct matrix representations , each of which may give different unfoldings , or may not admit any unfolding .",
    "almost all mutation - finite matrices have an unfolding .    given a permutation @xmath74 of the initial seed , construct the _",
    "composite permutation _",
    "@xmath415 to be the permutation given by :        [ thm : autsintounf ] given a skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath14 which unfolds to a matrix @xmath389 , with corresponding marked exchange graphs @xmath18 and @xmath416 , then @xmath417    choose an initial @xmath393 labelled seed @xmath418 , b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] which unfolds to the @xmath398 labelled seed @xmath411 , c { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] with index sets @xmath419 for @xmath420 and @xmath421 .",
    "let @xmath422 be an exchange graph automorphism , then @xmath109 corresponds to both a cluster automorphism @xmath423 of the cluster algebra @xmath424 , constructed from the initial seed @xmath47 , and to a mutation class automorphism @xmath425 .",
    "this mutation class automorphism in turn corresponds to an element of @xmath1 , so there is a sequence of @xmath426 mutations @xmath408 and a permutation @xmath64 such that @xmath427 all such automorphisms are constructed to have the same action on the initial seed @xmath47 , so @xmath428 , \\pm b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright } ) = { \\mathopen{}\\mathclose\\bgroup\\originalleft } (      { \\mathopen{}\\mathclose\\bgroup\\originalleft } [ f(\\beta_i ) { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright } ] , \\pm b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright } ) = \\phi_m(u ) = u \\cdot { \\mathopen{}\\mathclose\\bgroup\\originalleft } ( \\mu_{k_1 } \\mu_{k_2 } \\dotsb \\mu_{k_r } \\sigma { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright}).\\ ] ] in the unfolding , each mutation @xmath408 corresponds to the composite mutation @xmath409 and the permutation @xmath64 corresponds to the composite permutation @xmath429 , so the following commutes :        the automorphism @xmath109 corresponds to a cluster automorphism , so the matrix of the image of @xmath47 is @xmath365 . the seed @xmath430,\\pm b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] unfolds to @xmath431 , \\pm c { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] and",
    "hence @xmath432 acts on @xmath411 , c { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] to give a seed with the same matrix up to sign , so corresponds to a cluster automorphism of the cluster algebra constructed with @xmath411 , c { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] as the initial seed , and hence to an automorphism of the exchange graph @xmath392 .    by theorem  [ thm : mexchaut ]",
    "the marked exchange graph automorphisms correspond to cluster automorphisms , so for a skew - symmetrizable matrix @xmath14 which unfolds to @xmath389 and with corresponding cluster algebras @xmath424 and @xmath433 , theorem  [ thm : autsintounf ] implies @xmath434    .",
    "the dotted and dashed edges show how the marked exchange graph of type @xmath91 shown in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] unfolds . a dashed edge in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] corresponds to the composite mutation denoted by a consecutive pair of dashed edges in this figure .",
    "]    the matrix @xmath14 representing the dynkin diagram of type @xmath91 @xmath435 the matrix representing a quiver of dynkin type @xmath436 .",
    "the symmetrizing matrix of @xmath14 is given by @xmath437 so the @xmath91 marked exchange graph shown in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] embeds into the exchange graph of type @xmath436 shown in figure  [ fig : a3-exch ] .",
    "the dashed edges in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] correspond to the pairs of dashed edges representing composite mutations in figure  [ fig : a3-exch ] .",
    "dotted edges in figure  [ fig : b2-marked ] correspond to single dotted edges in figure  [ fig : a3-exch ] .",
    "the seed @xmath438 , b { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] unfolds to the seed @xmath439 , c      { \\aftergroup\\egroup\\originalright})$ ] and the cluster variables of these two seeds are related with @xmath440 as the symmetrizing matrix @xmath273 ensures that @xmath162 unfolds to two cluster variables .",
    "the automorphism @xmath441 given by rotation by @xmath442 takes the seed @xmath130 $ ] to @xmath443 $ ] and corresponds to the cluster automorphism @xmath444 given by @xmath445 this automorphism induces an automorphism of the exchange graph of @xmath436 given by a rotation along the embedded @xmath446 fixing the seeds with cyclic quivers and takes @xmath447 $ ] to @xmath448 $ ] which corresponds to the cluster automorphism @xmath449 given by @xmath450 however the automorphism could also correspond to the cluster automorphism @xmath451 where @xmath452 there is a single non - identity @xmath453 exchange graph automorphism which fixes the embedded @xmath446 , given by a reflection in the circle of the embedded subgraph and interchanging the two seeds with cyclic quivers .",
    "this then corresponds to the cluster automorphism @xmath454 given by @xmath455 such that @xmath456 .",
    "theorem  [ thm : autsintounf ] shows that cluster automorphisms of @xmath424 commute with unfolding the seeds , so a direct cluster automorphism @xmath457 preserves the exchange matrix @xmath14 , which when unfolded to @xmath458 must also preserve the exchange matrix @xmath389 and so is also a direct cluster automorphism .",
    "[ cor : direct_subgroup ] @xmath459 .",
    "in their paper introducing cluster automorphisms  @xcite assem , schiffler and shramchenko introduced the tagged mapping class group for surfaces with punctures . this group has been shown to coincide with the group of direct cluster automorphisms of the surface s corresponding cluster algebra .    given a surface with marked points @xmath460 the _ mapping class group _ of the surface is given by @xmath461 here @xmath462 is the group of orientation - preserving homeomorphisms from @xmath349 to itself which sends the set @xmath463 to itself , but does not necessarily fix @xmath463 nor the boundary of @xmath349 pointwise , and @xmath464 is the subgroup of homeomorphisms which are isotopic to the identity such that the isotopy fixes @xmath463 pointwise .",
    "the cluster structure given by triangulations of a surface with marked points was first studied by fomin , shapiro and thurston in  @xcite , where they show that flips of arcs in a triangulation coincide with mutations .",
    "however such a triangulation could contain self - folded triangles , and therefore arcs that can not be flipped ; to get around this problem , the authors introduced taggings on the arcs .",
    "a _ tagged arc _ is an arc which does not cut out a once - punctured monogon , where the enpoints are tagged either _ plain _ or _ notched _ , such that any endpoints on @xmath465 are tagged plain and if the endpoints of an arc coincide then they must be tagged the same .",
    "two tagged arcs are _ compatible _ if either their underlying arcs are the same and then at least one endpoint must be tagged in the same way , or the underlying arcs are not equal but are compatible . in this case , if they share an endpoint , the arcs must be tagged in the same way at that endpoint .",
    "a tagged triangulation is a maximal collection of compatible tagged arcs and a tagged flip is then defined in the same way as for triangulations , where a tagged arc is replaced with the unique other compatible tagged arc and these flips again correspond to mutations .",
    "see  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 7 ) or  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section 4 ) for more details .",
    "the _ tagged mapping class group _ of a surface @xmath460 with @xmath466 punctures is the semidirect product of the standard mapping class group of the surface with @xmath467 , @xmath468 where the elements of @xmath469 act as diffeomorphisms on the surface and elements of @xmath467 switch or preserve the tags on the tagged triangulation at each puncture .",
    "they showed that for discs and annuli without punctures as well as for certain discs with 1 or 2 punctures then the tagged mapping class group is isomorphic to the group of direct cluster automorphisms of the corresponding cluster algebra .",
    "the authors conjectured that this would be the case for almost all surfaces with marked points .",
    "brstle and qiu proved that this conjecture is true in  @xcite :              1 .   a sphere with @xmath476 marked points ; 2 .   an unpunctured disc with @xmath477 marked points on the boundary ; 3 .   a disc with a single puncture and one marked point on the boundary ; 4 .   a once - punctured disc with 2 or 4 marked points on the boundary ; 5 .   a twice - punctured disc with 2 marked points on the boundary",
    ",        diagrams correspond to triangulations of orbifolds in the same way that quivers correspond to triangulations of surfaces .",
    "a covering of the orbifold by a surface corresponds to an unfolding of the diagram to a quiver , in such a way that composite mutations of the quiver correspond to triangle flips in the triangulation of the surface , as discussed in  @xcite .    in their paper on the growth rate of cluster algebras , felikson , shapiro , thomas and tumarkin  @xcite defined the mapping class group of a cluster algebra @xmath479 to be the elements of @xmath1 which fix the initial exchange matrix up to a quotient by those elements of @xmath1 which fix the initial seed .",
    "elements of this group would then fix the initial exchange matrix and map the initial cluster to some other cluster in the mutation class , and hence would induce a direct cluster automorphism .    fix a marked orbifold @xmath21 with @xmath480 punctures . in  (",
    "* remark 4.15 ) the cluster mapping class group is argued to either contain the orbifold s mapping class group as a proper normal subgroup with quotient @xmath481 ( when @xmath482 , or when @xmath483 and the boundary non - empty ) or be isomorphic to the orbifold mapping class group ( when @xmath484 , or when @xmath485 and the boundary is empty ) .",
    "this orbifold has no punctures , so the tagged mapping class group is equal to the mapping class group .",
    "any element of the mapping class group must fix the orbifold point and permute the four boundary marked points .",
    "the only such permutations are rotations around the boundary , as any reflection would not preserve the orientation , hence the mapping class group is isomorphic to @xmath488 generated by a rotation by angle @xmath489 .",
    "this orbifold corresponds to the cluster algebra of dynkin type @xmath266 , which can be generated by the diagram in figure  [ fig : mcg - b3 ] .",
    "the cluster automorphism group of @xmath490 is the dihedral group with 8 elements : @xmath491 where @xmath488 is generated by the automorphism given by the action of @xmath492 on the initial cluster and @xmath486 by @xmath493 .",
    "this can be seen as the automorphisms of the marked exchange graph shown in figure  [ fig : b3-marked ] where the 4 squares are permuted while fixing the markings ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> cluster automorphisms have been shown to have links to the mapping class groups of surfaces , maximal green sequences and to exchange graph automorphisms for skew - symmetric cluster algebras . in this paper </S>",
    "<S> we generalise these results to the skew - symmetrizable case by introducing a marking on the exchange graph . </S>",
    "<S> many skew - symmetrizable matrices unfold to skew - symmetric matrices and we consider how cluster automorphisms behave under this unfolding with applications to coverings of orbifolds by surfaces .    </S>",
    "<S> * keywords : * cluster algebra ; quiver mutation ; cluster automorphism ; exchange graph ; mapping class group . </S>"
  ]
}
